summary: Epithelioid hemangioendothelioma (EHE) is a rare vascular cancer that is intermediate between angiosarcoma and hemangioma, but genetically distinct. It is a soft tissue sarcoma originating from endothelial cells and can occur in organs throughout the body, most frequently in the liver, lungs, bones, and skin. EHE typically has an indolent course, but can occasionally present as high-grade and aggressive.
causes: Balanced, reciprocal translocation t(1;3)(p36.3;q25) leading to TAZ-CAMTA1 fusion gene
Fusion gene resulting in constitutively active TAZ protein
Constitutive activation of YAP (orthologue of TAZ) due to a different translocation in ~10% of patients
diagnosis: Genetic testing for specific translocations (e.g., t(1;3)(p36.3;q25))
treatments: Tyrosine kinase inhibitors (e.g., sorafenib, sunitinib, pazopanib)
Multi-agent chemotherapy (for aggressive or unresponsive cases)
